S.FORM: asina-m sodel-bi sjurime ʦukʦu hɔtnɔ tʰiŋ-a ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: Long ago, in Sungdel, Syurime came into existence.

S.FORM: dʰane bjaksupa-nɔ ʦi-ŋɔ sjurime mɔ-di-m
S.TRANSL: Then, Bjaksupa had a child, Syurime.

S.FORM: ukmalɔ uk ŋiʦi bjak bjaksupa tsuikʰɔ-bika tsuikʰɔ-bi mɔ-ni-m ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: Once upon a time, there was Byaksupa from Tsuikho.

S.FORM: dʰanɔ tsuikʰɔ-bi rek ʦi-ʦɔ ʦʰɔʔ-ni ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: Then he had three children at Tsuikho.

S.FORM: bjaksupa-nɔ bjaksupa-nɔ dʰumsabu dipsuŋ kʰuʦ-a ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: Byaksupa's eldest went to Dipsung.

S.FORM: sodel dʰo kʰuŋ-a ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: He came up to Sungdel.

S.FORM: sonita kanʦʰa sodel kʰuŋ-a ʦʰa dʰo
S.TRANSL: The youngest, Sonita, came up to Sungdel.

S.FORM: kʰuw-a-lɔ ne dʰuŋŋje-lɔm jɔmɔla kok-to kok-to kʰuw-a ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: When he went to Dhungye he cut bananas as he went up.

S.FORM: dʰaiʔ dʰuŋŋje ɔ-kʰuw-a-lɔ ne
S.TRANSL: Then he didn't come up to Dhungye.

S.FORM: rɔmbʰɔ ipʰ-a-ba-m dʰiʔ-i ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: He encountered a sleeping boar.

S.FORM: sonita-kɔ oko kʰiba jɔ mɔ-di-m ʦʰa gene-kɔ getɔ
S.TRANSL: Sonita had with him Gene and Geto, both dogs.

S.FORM: dʰam kʰiba-kɔ dʰam rɔmbʰɔ dʰiʔ-si-m-me kɔl-to kɔl-to kʰo-si-lɔ ne jo sodel-bo suŋdeltar gʰud-usi-nɔ seʔ-si ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: Those dogs encountered a boar and chased him down to SungdelThar in Sungdel and brought him down and killed him.

S.FORM: seʔ-si-nɔ sonita dʰuŋja-ʦoptu hɔlɔnʦ-asi ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: After they killed him, Sonita and they went down from above Dhungye.

S.FORM: dʰanɔ sonita dʰin-to dʰin-to kʰiba-kɔ gʰɔʔ-nɔ harapu-go mɔ ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: Then, the dogs following him, Sonita went down to Harapu and stayed there.

S.FORM: dʰaiʔnɔ-ŋɔ um mɔ-di-m-me dʰaiʔnɔ-ŋɔ ʦi-ʦɔ ʦʰuk-to ʦʰuk-to pu sjurime-kɔ kurime rɔtʰɔma ʦʰɔʔ-ni ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: Then after he was there, he had children: Syurime, Kurime and Rathama were born.

S.FORM: dʰanɔ sjurime pu oko dʰuwaŋɔ ʦʰupa mɔ-di tʰe rilipʰu-ʦɔ hɔp-ka ʣʰara ʣʰara ʦjuʔ-ka koʔ-ka kubimɔpa heʔe-m tajami
S.TRANSL: One of them, Syurime, was very well-behaved, excelled at the bow, and knew and could do everything, and was wise like a shaman..

S.FORM: dʰanɔ dʰaiʔnɔ-ŋɔ mɔ-ni-m-bi uk ŋiʦi rɔtʰama-nɔ bɔkʦi-kɔ rɔtʰama-nɔ-nɔ bɔkʦi oko pu dɔni kʰoʔ-ni-m ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: Then one day, of the two younger siblings, one, Rathama, was sent away in mariage.

S.FORM: mɔkʦi-bi juku jo makpa-lɔm gʰud-uni-m tʰe-m
S.TRANSL: The son-in-law brought her down to Makpa, to his place.

S.FORM: dʰanɔ selanam mɔ bɔkʦi minʦuma-ʦi-ja ne kuku-nɔ del kʰuw-a ʦʰa sodel
S.TRANSL: A while later, the younger sister's child came up to his uncle's village, at Sungdel.

S.FORM: sodel-bi dʰuwaŋɔ gɔ-di-m ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: There were many things in Sungdel.

S.FORM: ʣʰara ʣʰara silpʰi-ʦɔ sumɔ kɔl-ka-ʦɔ jɔ kʰɔlɔ gɔ-di-lɔ ne anɔ mɔʣi mɔʣja ne ʦʰul-nasi tʰe
S.TRANSL: There were many birds, and many things to hunt, and everything was there, and the nephew felt envious.

S.FORM: anɔ kuku-nɔ basakʰɔm jaʔ-kʰo tʰe
S.TRANSL: He came to like his uncle's place.

S.FORM: dʰaiʔlɔ kuku-kɔ uk ŋiʦi kʰuʦ-asi tʰe
S.TRANSL: Then one day, he went out with his uncle.

S.FORM: sapko mu-di sumɔ kɔl-di
S.TRANSL: They went to the forest, to hunt and chase animals.

S.FORM: dʰaiʔlɔ dʰoku rjuʔni-gobo ipʰ-asi-lɔ
S.TRANSL: Then they slept, up at Ryuni.

S.FORM: ana kuku-wa lu tʰe
S.TRANSL: And his uncle said:

S.FORM: sjurime-a a-kulu laʔ-nɔ ipʰ-a ibi ʦukʦu-ʦɔ ho-ni lu tʰe-m ne kulu dʰepd-u-nɔ ipʰ-a tʰe
S.TRANSL: Syurime told him: hide your face when you sleep, the gods will come, and he covered his face and slept.

S.FORM: dʰaiʔlɔ ʦukʦu-ʦɔ a-ʦʰend-uni-lɔ bʰund-uni tʰe sjurime
S.TRANSL: And the gods, when they couldn't recognize him, scolded Syurime.

S.FORM: umbika an ne laʦi wɔ pʰjakpa ɔ-ʣup-nisina-m ʦʰa a-waʔriwa ɔ-gɔ-m ʦʰa mɔnʣi lu del ɔt-ʦisi kʰuʦ-a a-kim luʔ-nɔ jokim
S.TRANSL: "You are a liar, your behaviour is not good; his habits are bad (nephew's), return your nephew to the village, take him to his house" they said.

S.FORM: bojo gʰud-usi-nɔ bojo pʰiŋ-su ʦʰa anɔ mɔnʣi-nɔ pu sumɔ kɔl-ka sumɔ set-ka ana sagowa-bi tʰiŋ-a-ʣa-m ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: He brought him down to Boyo, and sent him away, but the desire to chase and kill prey was still in his (the nephew's) heart.

S.FORM: dʰailʔlɔ dʰam ɔ-laiʔ-mu-ŋɔ kuku-wa kim pʰiŋ-su-lɔ ne mama luʔ ʦʰa selaʔa ʣi gʰɔlpa ʦʰɔʔ-nɔ
S.TRANSL: Then he was unable to satisfy his desire when his uncle sent him away, and when he grew bigger, he said to his mother:

S.FORM: lu aŋa maʔa asina kuku-wa aŋɔ sagowa a-tim-mu-ŋɔ pʰiŋ-gʰu-ʦu-m
S.TRANSL: "Hey, mother, yesterday uncle, without feeling any pity (=pressing his soul), sent me away.

S.FORM: aŋ kuku-nɔ del kʰɔlɔ aŋa aŋ bi-mu ʦʰo kuka
S.TRANSL: Uncle must give me his entire village.

S.FORM: kʰuʦ-ani-nɔ luʦ-ani
S.TRANSL: Go and tell him.

S.FORM: a-bi-tɔ-kʰo aŋa kuku-kɔ ke-su kuku seʔ-dɔ dja ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: If he doesn't give it to me, I will fight with him and kill him," he said.

S.FORM: ʔe laʦi mama dja ʦʰa ʔe laʦi
S.TRANSL: "Hey, liar," mother said.

S.FORM: hɔʔem ma na kuku-ŋɔ kɔl-mu lam-dana ma
S.TRANSL: "How is it that you try to chase your uncle?

S.FORM: kuku-nɔ del pʰi-m pʰi-dana ma
S.TRANSL: Beg your uncle for his village.

S.FORM: an hɔtnɔ be-na ma a-be-na lu ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: How will he give it to you? He won't give it to you," she said.

S.FORM: bi-tɔ si-tɔ sɔmɔ jɔ ɔ-ʦjuʔ-dɔ
S.TRANSL: "Whether he will give it to me or what I have no idea.

S.FORM: aŋ kuku-wa bi-mu ʦʰo ana del
S.TRANSL: He must give me his village.

S.FORM: meʔ-kʰo aŋ kʰɔ-tɔ-kʰa seʔ-dɔ lu ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: If not, I will go to him and kill him," he said.

S.FORM: dʰaiʔ lu kʰuʦ-a-nɔ ʦelbu luʔ ʦʰa kʰuʦ-a ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: "Well, go tell your family," he said and she left.

S.FORM: sjurime ana bɔkʦi kʰuw-a-nɔ sjurime lu ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: So Syurime's younger sister went up and said to Syurime:

S.FORM: bubu asina ne mɔkʦi-ja ne mɔʣja ne ani basakʰɔm jaʔ-a ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: "Brother, your nephew likes your home.

S.FORM: dʰaiʔlɔ ne kʰɔlɔ ʣʰara sumɔ dʰokʰo-lɔ ne lalu mu-da ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: When he saw all the prey, he fell in love.

S.FORM: ida ne basakʰɔm-nɔ ida ani basakʰɔm pʰi-da
S.TRANSL: He is begging for your home.

S.FORM: hɔiʔ mo-ni-m mɔ dʰai kɔ ne aŋ ne ki-tɔ kuku seʔ-dɔ de-di hɔiʔ mo-ni-m ma
S.TRANSL: What is it he will do? He said "I'll fight with him and kill him". What will you do?"

S.FORM: dʰaiʔ de-kʰo kʰo-ne ma aŋ ʦeʦelu umbika kʰo-ne ma aŋa seʔ-dɔ luʔ ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: "If he said that, then I'll bring him away to the hilltop and then I'll kill him," he said.
"Or, I'll give my nephew a little (of my land),"
S.FORM: ke heʦi-ʦɔ biŋ-dɔ heʦi umbi muʣa ne nara
dja ʦʰa umbika pʰiŋ-gʰuʔd-u ʦʰa bigame joku ʣɔllesor-bi ɔ-gɔ-m luʔ ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: he said and sent her away, he sent his sister down to Jallesor.

S.FORM: lu kuku-wa heʦi-ʦɔ be-na tʰe dʰam heʦi munɔʣaʔe ma
S.TRANSL: She said:" your uncle will give you some land. Cultivate that land."
The nephew said: "I don't want a little. I'll walk to the village and fight with my uncle."
S.FORM: ʣɔmlɔ ne dja ʦʰa heʦiʦi ɔ-ʦjuʔ-dɔ aŋ del-bi kuku-kɔ ki-di lɔmtʰi-m dja ʦʰa
kʰɔlɔ bʰag-ʦɔ bʰu-ʦɔ hati-ʦɔ kʰoʔ-nɔ kʰuʦ-a ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: And he brought all the tigers and elephants (from his own village) and went.

S.FORM: lɔrai mu-di kuku-kɔ um-bika kʰuʦ-a-nɔ suŋdel-bi hɔ-ʣa-nɔ suŋdel-bi ʦokʦokkja-nɔ pʰar-bi lɔ kʰund-u-nɔ nuru bʰoʔ ʦʰa gɔldʰɔk-ʦɔ bʰoʔ ʦʰa umbika
S.TRANSL: In order to wage war with his uncle, he went from there to Sungdel, and buried a stone at the base of a tree, and tied the tigers and elephants to the stone.

S.FORM: kuku-lai ʦjuʔri bi tʰe aŋ hukʰo-ʦu ki-di bʰjaʔ onera
S.TRANSL: He sent his uncle the message: "I have arrived, come fight."

S.FORM: dʰaiʔlɔ ne kuku-wa dʰokʰo ana mɔkʦi hɔkʰuw-a-m ana hobu seʔ-di
S.TRANSL: And the uncle saw that his nephew had arrived to kill him.

S.FORM: dʰaiʔlɔ sjurime ne sɔmɔ mu-mu sɔmɔ mu-mu ʦʰɔʔ tʰe
S.TRANSL: And Syurime went "what shall I do?"
Then after wondering what to do, Syurime went to Boyotar.
S.FORM: dʰaiʔlɔ sɔmɔ mu-mu sɔmɔ mu-mu ʦʰɔʔ-lɔ ne sjurime ne bojotar lɔʦ-a ʦʰa bojotar lɔʦ-a tʰe
lɔʦ-a-nɔ ana rilipʰu-nɔ lipʰuwa-nɔ rilipʰu-kɔ ja ebo dakʰo kʰɔnd-u-nɔ dakʰo kʰɔnd-u-nɔ duku nɔm-ʦoptu-lɔm rilipʰu leʔ-su ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: He went out and with his bow and arrow said a spell here and there, and shot off an arrow towards the sun above.

S.FORM: dʰam rilipʰu ne susumeɔ ʦʰɔʔ-nɔ tan-nasi ʦʰa dumluku butu mina heʔŋɔ gʰɔlpa-ŋɔ gʰɔlpa sɔn-nasi ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: That arrow turned into Susume and came down at Dumluku and lay there, like a very big human.

S.FORM: sɔnʦ-a-tan-nasi ʦʰa dʰanɔ
S.TRANSL: He lay there.

S.FORM: luʔ ʦʰa uma-ʔa luʔ ani kʰuʦ-ani-nɔ duku dumluku-butu sin-ani umbi oko laso tan-nasi-m go tʰiŋ-a-m go
S.TRANSL: He said: "Go up above to Dumluku, see a sign that has descended there, that has been created.

S.FORM: umu ani-ja kur-ini-nɔ gʰuʔ-mu ne a-ʦapʰ-ini
S.TRANSL: You will be unable to carry it and bring it down.

S.FORM: umu ani-ja ana ŋiʦo kʰur pʰɔʔmal heʦiʦi kʰepʦ-ani gʰukʦ-ani hei oko sɔ-bi sikʦ-ani-nɔ luʔ-ni ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: Carve off his ear, arms, legs, and stick them on a stick and bring them down," he said to them.

S.FORM: dʰanɔ pʰiŋ-uni ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: And he sent them off.

S.FORM: hɔbaʦ-ani-lɔ ne he nɔm ruʔbukd-u-m ho
S.TRANSL: When they arrived, there was something so high as to reach the sun.

S.FORM: nɔm ruʔbukd-u-m sɔsɔjɔjɔ sɔnʦ-a-ba-m
S.TRANSL: He was as high as the sun, blocking the road.

S.FORM: dʰam dʰaisaro gʰɔl dʰaisaro gʰɔlpa wɔ mina heʔe-m sɔmɔ wɔ sɔmɔ wɔ
S.TRANSL: He was sort of like a man, a very large man.

S.FORM: ipʰ-a-ba-m um um-bika ne umʦaʔ jɔ kur-mu-nɔ gʰuʔ-mu ɔ-ʦap-ka
S.TRANSL: They were unable to carry and bring down the sleeping one.

S.FORM: nu misi kʰur pʰɔʔmal heʦiʦi kʰepd-uni-nɔ oko sɔ-bi sik-uni-nɔ gʰud-uni ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: They carved a bit of his nose, eyes, mouth, arms, legs, and put them on a stick and brought him down.

S.FORM: dʰanɔ bojo-bi hoʔgʰud-uni-nɔ sjurime bi-ni-m ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: They brought them down to Boyo and gave him to Syurime.

S.FORM: sjurime dʰam dʰam ʦʰem pʰɔd-u-nɔ kʰund-u-nɔ tʰir-u-nɔ ʦʰem ʦʰepd-u ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: Syurime fastened the stick and buried it and stabililized it.

S.FORM: ʦʰem ʦʰepd-u-lɔ ne aʣi oko sumdikʰa wɔ tʰiŋ-a ʦʰa dʰam sina
S.TRANSL: When he stuck it in, a spring was formed.

S.FORM: sumdikʰa tʰiŋ-a-kʰa jɔ juku anɔ bʰanʣa mɔnʣai mɔnʣa mɔ-di-m-bo kʰuʦ-a-nɔ seʔ-su-ni ʦʰa ma ne
S.TRANSL: That river source was created and down below was the place where the nephew was, and he went there and killed him.

S.FORM: sjɔʔ-kʰo-ni ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: (The rivers) washed away the nephew.

S.FORM: dʰaiʔnɔ sjɔʔd-uni-nɔ bʰanʣa pʰiŋ-u ʦʰa bʰanʣa seʔ-su ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: (The waters) washed him away, sent him away, killed him.

S.FORM: duku ru ru bʰe-m ʦʰa ana ru ŋiʦ-a jɔ umbika duku dʰo ʦeʦelu-lɔm lɔʦ-a ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: And his soul hurt, and he went up to the hilltops.

S.FORM: duku duku hɔripokʰəri epoti sur-nasi ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: And he went up to Haripokhari and washed.

S.FORM: dʰanɔ kʰaiʔpa kʰɔn-ʦu det-ʦu dja-kʰa umbika
S.TRANSL: "I am terrible," he said.

S.FORM: dʰanɔ he ja ebo kɔl-nɔ sumɔ kɔl-to kɔl-to ja-la majum-lɔm hɔbaʦ-a ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: And then, hunting, he arrived at Mayum.

S.FORM: dʰaiʔlɔ um-bo hɔbaʦ-a-lɔ majum-bi oko sano min gʰa-ʣa-m dʰokʰo ʦʰa pʰuli-bi
S.TRANSL: Then, when he arrived there, in Mayum, he saw a small fire burning in a cave.

S.FORM: dʰam pʰuli-go wɔ ne mɔ-m ʦʰa bantawa-ʦɔ-nɔ bigjame
S.TRANSL: There was someone inside the cave, a Bantawa girl.

S.FORM: dʰaiʔlɔ asu mo-ni ibi aŋ ne tʰam-to hule-ʦu a-hobu-ŋɔ ʦʰuk-ʦu
S.TRANSL: "Who is there? I arrived here, having gotten lost, I am alone.

S.FORM: sɔŋai-bi hɔtnɔ mumu-wa min dʰokʰo-ŋa min-bi mu-tɔ
S.TRANSL: I saw the fire, and I (want to) sit in the fire ('s heat).

S.FORM: mu-mu bi-ʦu ne luʔ-ni ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: Allow me to sit here" he said to her.

S.FORM: ʦʰoʔema bʰjaʔ-ni aŋ ja ɔ-hobu-ŋɔ mu-tɔ
S.TRANSL: "OK, come in, I too am alone.

S.FORM: asu wɔ ani
S.TRANSL: Who are you?

S.FORM: hɔtnɔ hɔt hɔtnɔ hɔle-ni ibi ne
S.TRANSL: How did you get here?

S.FORM: asu jɔ ɔ-hule-ni-m ma hɔiʔlɔ ani hɔlja-ni
S.TRANSL: Noone comes here, so how is it that you came?

S.FORM: kɔpa mu-ka wɔ
S.TRANSL: Where do you live?

S.FORM: hɔiʔ mu-ka wɔ
S.TRANSL: What do you do?

S.FORM: haka hɔ-ni-m luʔ-ni ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: Why did you come?" she said to him.

S.FORM: dʰaiʔlɔ ne aŋ ne sjurime sodel-bi sodel-nɔ ʦi
S.TRANSL: "I am Syurime, from Sungdel.

S.FORM: sodel-lɔŋka-ŋɔ gʰuk-ʦu-m jɔ sumɔ kɔl-to kɔl-to bik-ʦu-lɔ
S.TRANSL: I came down from Sungdel, I came down as I was hunting, and I came here.

S.FORM: ɔmnɔ ja ɔ-kim hubaiʔ-mu ɔ-ʦapd-uŋa tʰam-ʦu
S.TRANSL: Today, I wasn't able to reach my house, and I got lost.

S.FORM: dʰaiʔlɔ min dʰokʰ-uŋa-lɔ min-bi mu-mu deʔ-ʦu-kʰa hu-ʦu-lɔ ani dʰiʔ-nani
S.TRANSL: Then when I saw the fire, I wanted to be by the fire, and then I met you.

S.FORM: bi-ʦu ne ɔ-bi-tɔ ne
S.TRANSL: Give it to me... Or will she not give it to me (a place to stay)?"

S.FORM: lo ʦʰoʔo bʰjaʔ mɔ-ni ma bʰja-ni ʦʰa mɔ-di ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: "OK, come" and they stayed.

S.FORM: dʰaiʔlɔ ne um-nɔ-nɔ dɔʔʣam laiʔ-mu ʣi-mu ne kʰɔʔ-mu lɔ ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: Then he took out his snack and ate, and he felt embarassed.

S.FORM: sjurime-nɔ luʣɔm-nɔ subja gɔ-m ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: Syurime's bread was of millet.

S.FORM: dʰanɔ kʰisa-bi pir-di-m ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: So he hid it in his pocket.

S.FORM: aʣitʰɔŋka laʔ-a ʦʰa anɔ pipi-ja bi ʦʰa subja
S.TRANSL: Later, the grandmother (=the woman) took out some bread and gave it to him.

S.FORM: umʦɔ-nɔ luʣɔm-nɔ subja gɔ-di-m ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: Their bread was made of millet.

S.FORM: ʣɔm-nɔ subja laʔ-ni-nɔ bi-ni-m-me uma jɔ anɔ luʣɔm-nɔ subja biʔ ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: After she pulled out and gave him her rice bread, he too pulled out his millet bread and gave it to her.

S.FORM: bi-si-m-me bibi mɔ-si-m-me lalu muiʔ-mu mɔ-si ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: After they exchanged bread, they began to love each other.

S.FORM: tɔpa-kɔ tɔma-kɔ ʦʰɔʔ-si ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: They became husband and wife.

S.FORM: umbika mumu kur-mu-da ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: And then she was with child.

S.FORM: ne disja ne disja ʦʰɔʔ-ɔ-m-me ne ebo kʰartamʦʰa ɔt-nasi ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: Time went by, and she returned to Khartamcha.

S.FORM: ʦukʦu sjurime ne jakko pu ʦi mumu kur-mu-da ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: There, in Yakko, Syurime impregnated her.

S.FORM: umbika kʰartamʦʰa bʰjaʔ-nɔ kʰɔlɔ sumɔ seʔ-e-m-ʦɔ-me ʦʰem ʦʰepd-u ʦʰa dʰailɔ
S.TRANSL: In Khartamcha, he said a prayer for all the animals he had killed.

S.FORM: ʦʰem ʦʰepd-u-lɔ ne um-nɔ del-nɔ nu ne ʦʰemsune ʦʰɔʔ-ɔ ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: When he prayed, the name of the village became Chemchire.

S.FORM: ʦʰem ʦʰepd-u ʦʰa ʦʰem ʦʰepd-u-nɔ sɔ miʦ-a-nɔ jo tʰɔm-bi kʰuʦ-a ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: He went to that place below where the trees had died (??)

S.FORM: dʰanɔ bigjame-nɔ umbi kʰuʦ-a-m sɔmɔ jɔ ʣi-ka du-ka ɔ-bi ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: Then when he went to his sister's place, she wouldn't give him anything to eat and drink.

S.FORM: soʔwa miʦ-a-m bela sumɔ jɔ teti ɔ-seʔ-e-m ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: When he was hungry, he couldn't kill any prey.

S.FORM: heʦiʦi seʔ-e-m ka ɔr ɔrko-nɔ bɔkʦi-nɔ hɔbaʦ-a ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: After killing a little, he arrived at his other younger sibling's house.

S.FORM: del-bi-m ʦʰekuma-ʦi-ʦɔ-nɔ dʰam-wa pu tʰoŋba-ʦɔ tʰoba-ʦɔ ʦin-ʦɔ kʰɔlɔ hal-kʰɔnd-u ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: At the house of his sisters in this village, she had spread out all sorts of beers for him.

S.FORM: toma ne to-kʰɔnd-u ʦʰa kʰɔlɔ bi-da ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: He offered them Toma, and gave them everything.

S.FORM: dʰaiʔnɔ bi-nɔ kʰuʦ-a ʦʰa dʰo bʰusunja-bi hɔlɔnʦ-a-m
S.TRANSL: Then, after he gave it to them and went, he arrived up at Bhusunya.

S.FORM: dʰam ŋis-u ʦʰa-kʰa ɔrko nana jɔ bʰul-to bʰjaʔ-nɔ aŋ jɔ bi-ʦu dja-nɔ
S.TRANSL: Having heard this, another sister came running and said "Give me some too".

S.FORM: lu madago anɔ jam kʰaratamʦam tʰul-mu ʣam luʔ-nɔ bi tʰe-m um kʰartamʦa del
S.TRANSL: "Hey, you go cultivate the bad land" and he gave it to her, and it became Khartamcha.

S.FORM: dʰaiʔnɔ bi-ni-nɔ bʰjaʔ ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: Then he gave it and came.

S.FORM: sodel bʰjaʔ-nɔ ne sodel bʰjaʔ-nɔ mɔ ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: Then after coming to Sungdel, he stayed.

S.FORM: kʰɔlɔ-ŋɔ sodel bʰjaʔ-nɔ mɔ-nɔ mɔ-kɔ ʦʰeʦʰelu-bi ʦem-nasi ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: After coming to Sungdel, he stayed, and played on the hillside.

S.FORM: dʰailɔ ʦemd-u-m kɔŋkʰa-bi mɔ-nɔ dʰaiʔnɔ s..m.. mɔ sumdikʰa
S.TRANSL: He stayed in the water he was playing in, and he played, and he was in a sacred spring.

S.FORM: dʰanɔ oko sjuri susume ma dʰaiʔnɔ tʰiŋ-u tʰe-m
S.TRANSL: Then he created a Susume.

S.FORM: dʰaiʔlɔ dʰusaba jɔ sjurime pu kim-bi-m kʰɔlɔ-nɔ dʰubi-m ʦukʦu de-ki-nɔ sjɔkʰɔnʦ-iki sjɔkʰɔn-uʦu
S.TRANSL: Even nowadays, we say Syurime is the father of the gods of the house, and we do puja to him, "do puja to me"

S.FORM: umu ʦukʦu mo-ni-lɔ oko pi jɔ kʰuiʔ-mu ʦʰo pi bi-mu ʦʰo siru-ʦɔ kʰɔlɔ hal-mu ʦʰo-nɔ mu-mu ʦʰo
S.TRANSL: We must kill a chicken and give it to him, and spread out all our rice.

S.FORM: hetnɔ dʰaiʔnɔ jakko bʰospur-bi mu-m ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: So this is how he created Yakko (=Mayam) in Bhospur.

S.FORM: bʰospur-bi-m pipi-kɔ mur-kɔ ʦʰen-mu subja-lɔŋka ʦʰɔʔ-kʰa luʣɔm-nɔ subja kʰip-mu pərne tʰeʔ-e-m-kʰa heʔnɔ sjurime-a pu hetna tʰiŋ-a-m ʦʰa
S.TRANSL: Because the god couple recognized each other in Bhospur through the bread, we must cook rice and millet bread, Syurime created all this.

S.FORM: hetnɔ-ŋɔ m...-ma sjurime dʰusaba kʰɔlɔ-nɔ dʰubi repʦ-iki-m rep-mu ʦʰo
S.TRANSL: Because he did this, we respect Syurime as the oldest of our gods.
